hints_html: Try (lightly) shading out the portions of the axes where the function is undefined. Then try adding in each piece of information from b-e, one step at a time.
hints_latex:
Try (lightly) shading out the portions of the axes where the function is
undefined. Then try adding in each piece of information from b-e, one
step at a time.
hints_raw: Try (lightly) shading out the portions of the axes where the function is undefined.  Then try adding in each piece of information from b-e, one step at a time.
question: 8 (f)
sols_html:
Using the information from parts (a) - (e), we draw the graph as follows.

First, we know that the function is undefined outside of \(\displaystyle (-2,2)\) so we will shade out that portion of the graph.

Now we add in the two x-intercepts at \(-\sqrt{3}\) and \(\sqrt{3}\). We also include the information about the asymptotes - both \(x = -2\) and \(x = 2\) were asymptotes, with the function going to \(-\infty\).

Finally, incorporating the information from (d) and (e) about increase/decrease and concavity, and the maximum at x = 0, we connect the dots and finish the drawing.
sols_latex:
Using the information from parts (a) - (e), we draw the graph as
follows.

First, we know that the function is undefined outside of
$\displaystyle (-2,2)$ so we will shade out that portion of the graph.

Now we add in the two \emph{x}-intercepts at $-\sqrt{3}$ and $\sqrt{3}$.
We also include the information about the asymptotes - both $x = -2$ and
$x = 2$ were asymptotes, with the function going to $-\infty$.

Finally, incorporating the information from (d) and (e) about
increase/decrease and concavity, and the maximum at \emph{x = 0}, we
connect the dots and finish the drawing.

\includegraphics[width=0.5\textwidth]{../json_data/MATH110/April_2011/ScienceMathExamResourcesCoursesMath110April2011Question8f.png}
sols_raw:
Using the information from parts (a) - (e), we draw the graph as follows.

First, we know that the function is undefined outside of <math>\displaystyle (-2,2)</math> so we will shade out that portion of the graph. 

Now we add in the two ''x''-intercepts at <math>-\sqrt{3}</math> and <math>\sqrt{3}</math>.  We also include the information about the asymptotes - both <math>x = -2</math> and <math>x = 2</math> were asymptotes, with the function going to <math>-\infty</math>.  

Finally, incorporating the information from (d) and (e) about increase/decrease and concavity, and the maximum at ''x = 0'', we connect the dots and finish the drawing.

statement_html:
Let

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle f(x) = \ln\left(4-x^2\right)\end{aligned}\]

Sketch the graph of \(f\), indicating all you have found in the previous parts of the question.
statement_latex:
Let

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
f(x) = \ln\left(4-x^2\right)
\end{align*}

Sketch the graph of $f$, indicating all you have found in the previous
parts of the question.
statement_raw:
Let

:<math> \displaystyle
f(x) = \ln\left(4-x^2\right)
</math>

Sketch the graph of &fnof;, indicating all you have found in the previous parts of the question.
